caption: Figure 2: Consider three networks (a), (b), (c) in the two-dimensional space. Two networks (G1, x) and (G1, y) have x<sub>i</sub>-x<sub>j</sub> / ||x<sub>i</sub>-x<sub>j</sub>|| = y<sub>i</sub>-y<sub>j</sub> / ||y<sub>i</sub>-y<sub>j</sub>||, (i, j) ∈ E but are not related by a combination of translations and scaling. Their corresponding matrix-weighted Laplacian has rank(L) = 4 < 2n – 3. In contrast, the network (G2, z) (having one more edge (1,3)) satisfies rank(L) = 5 = 2n – 3; Three networks (d), (e), (f) are considered in the three dimensional space, the matrix-weighted Laplacian of networks (G3, x') and (G3, y') has rank(L) = 19 < 3n – 4, while network (G4, z') (have an additional edge (1,8)) has rank(L) = 20 = 3n – 4.
description: This figure shows six different matrix-weighted graphs, three in 2D and three in 3D space.  It illustrates how adding edges to a graph affects the rank of its Laplacian matrix, which is related to the consensus properties of the network. The caption highlights the relationship between graph structure (number of edges), dimensionality, and the rank of the Laplacian matrix.
section: 5 Matrix-weighted consensus of double-integrators without relative velocity measurements using two time delays

caption: Figure 2: Consider three networks (a), (b), (c) in the two-dimensional space. Two networks (G1, x) and (G1, y) have xᵢ - xⱼ / ||xᵢ - xⱼ|| = yᵢ - yⱼ / ||yᵢ - yⱼ||, (i, j) ∈ E but are not related by a combination of translations and scaling. Their corresponding matrix-weighted Laplacian has rank(L) = 4 < 2n – 3. In contrast, the network (G2, z) (having one more edge (1,3) satisfies rank(L) = 5 = 2n – 3; Three networks (d), (e), (f) are considered in the three dimensional space, the matrix-weighted Laplacian of networks (G3, x') and (G3, y') has rank(L) = 19 < 3n – 4, while network (G4, z') (have an additional edge (1,8)) has rank(L) = 20 = 3n – 4.
description: This figure shows examples of matrix-weighted graphs in 2D and 3D space. It illustrates how the rank of the matrix-weighted Laplacian, a key concept in the paper, relates to the connectivity of the graph.  Specifically, it highlights the difference between graphs that satisfy the condition rank(L) = 2n-3 (or 3n-4 in 3D) and those that do not, emphasizing the importance of sufficient connectivity for achieving consensus.
section: 5 Matrix-weighted consensus of double-integrators without relative velocity measurements using two time delays

caption: Figure 4: The simulations results with (a) τ = 0.1 and (b) τ = 0.25 are given.
description: This figure presents simulation results for a matrix-weighted consensus network of 10 agents under different uniform time delays.  Subfigure (a) shows the asymptotic convergence to a consensus state when the time delay τ is 0.1s. Subfigure (b) illustrates that the system becomes unstable when the time delay τ is increased to 0.25s.  The plots show the trajectories of the state variables for each agent (x1i, x2i, x3i) over time. The x-axis represents time in seconds, and the y-axis represents the value of the state variables.
section: A.5.1 Matrix-weighted consensus models with time delays

caption: Figure 5: The simulation results of the matrix-weighted consensus model (7) with multiple delays. The system asymptotically achieves consensus for τ₁ = 0.05, τ₂ = 0.1 and τ₃ = 0.15 but being unstable for τ₁ = 0.05, τ₂ = 0.1 and τ₃ = 0.2.
description: This figure presents simulation results for a matrix-weighted consensus model with heterogeneous time delays.  Subfigure (a) shows the system converging to a consensus when the delays are τ₁ = 0.05s, τ₂ = 0.10s, and τ₃ = 0.15s.  In contrast, subfigure (b) demonstrates that the system becomes unstable when the delay τ₃ is increased to 0.20s, while τ₁ and τ₂ remain the same. This illustrates the impact of heterogeneous delays on the stability of the matrix-weighted consensus system.
section: A.5.1 Matrix-weighted consensus models with time delays

caption: Figure 6: The simulation results of the matrix-weighted consensus model (8) with different values of T1, T2 and k.
description: This figure shows simulation results for a matrix-weighted consensus model of double integrators, varying parameters to observe the effects on consensus.  Subfigures (a) through (l) display the state trajectories (x₁, x₂, x₃) of the agents over time. The simulations explore the effects of different combinations of time delays (τ₁, τ₂) and control gain (k) on the system's stability and convergence to a consensus.  The results illustrate how changes in these parameters influence whether the system reaches a consensus or becomes unstable.
section: A.5.2 Matrix-weighted consensus models with time delays

caption: Figure 7: The simulation results (trajectories of  xᵢ and bearing error) of the network localization update law (6) with τ = 0.1 (sec) ((a)–(b)), and τ = 0.2 (sec) ((c)–(d)).
description: This figure presents simulation results for a bearing-based network localization algorithm with a uniform constant time delay.  Subfigures (a) and (b) show the results for a time delay of 0.1 seconds, while subfigures (c) and (d) show the results for a time delay of 0.2 seconds.  The results illustrate the trajectories of the estimated positions of the nodes (xᵢ) and the corresponding bearing errors.  The simulation demonstrates the impact of the time delay on the algorithm's performance and its ability to converge to an accurate localization.
section: 6 Bearing-based network localization under time delays

caption: Figure 8: The simulation results (trajectories of xᵢ and bearing error) of the network localization update law (8) with (a) & (b) τ₁ = 0.1, τ₂ = 0.2, τ₃ = 0.3 (sec) and (c) & (d) τ₁ = 0.1, τ₂ = 0.2, τ₃ = 0.35 (sec).
description: This figure presents the simulation results for the bearing-based network localization algorithm with heterogeneous time delays.  Subfigures (a) and (b) show the results for time delays τ₁ = 0.1, τ₂ = 0.2, and τ₃ = 0.3 seconds. Subfigures (c) and (d) display the results when the time delay τ₃ is increased to 0.35 seconds. The plots illustrate the trajectories of the estimated node positions (xᵢ) and the corresponding bearing errors over time. The results demonstrate the algorithm's performance under different delay scenarios, indicating stability for the former set of delays and instability when τ₃ is increased to 0.35 seconds.
section: A.5.2 Bearing-based network localization with time delays

caption: Figure 7: The simulation results (trajectories of xᵢ and bearing error) of the network localization update law (6) with τ = 0.1 (sec) ((a)–(b)), and τ = 0.2 (sec) ((c)–(d)).
description: This figure shows the simulation results of the network localization update law (6) with two different time delays: τ = 0.1 seconds and τ = 0.2 seconds.  Each subfigure presents a different aspect of the simulation: (a) and (c) show the trajectories of the estimated node positions (xᵢ) over time in 3D space. The initial estimates, trajectories, and estimates at t=10 and t=20 seconds are displayed to show the evolution of the localization process.  (b) and (d) illustrate the bearing errors, which represent the difference between measured and estimated bearing angles.  These graphs show how the bearing errors decrease with time for the smaller time delay (τ = 0.1s) indicating successful convergence to a localized solution. However, for the larger time delay (τ = 0.2s), the bearing errors oscillate more significantly and do not converge as fast, indicating potential instability.  The simulation demonstrates the impact of time delays on the accuracy and stability of the bearing-based network localization process.
section: Bearing-based network localization under time delays
